articles.title: Nmap for Pentester: Port Status
articles.content:
# Nmap for Pentester: Port Status

Hello friends, several times you might have used NMAP to performing Network scanning for enumerating active Port services of target machine but in some scenarios you don’t get simple message if a port open or close.

# Let's Begin

# Requirement
* Attacker’s IP: 192.168.1.109 [Kali Linux]
* Target’s IP: 192.168.1.119 [Ubuntu]

The states of ports are not their essential properties; it depicts how nmap sees them. In nmap a port is divided into six states:

1. Open: This state means that an application on the target machine is listening for connections/packets on that port.
2. Closed: This state means ports have no application listening on them, though they could open up at any time.
3. Filtered: This state means that a firewall, filter, or other network obstacle is blocking the port so that Nmap cannot tell whether it is open or closed.
4. Unfiltered: ports are classified as unfiltered when they are responsive to Nmap’s probes, but Nmap cannot determine whether they are open or closed.
5. Open/Filtered: This indicates that the filtering or opening of the port occurred, but Nmap couldn’t establish the state.
6. Closed/Filtered: This indicates that the filtering or closing of the port occurred, but Nmap couldn’t establish the state.

# Open Port
In this case a service or application running on a port is actively accepting TCP, UDP connections. We transmit TCP packets to the target machine’s port 80. The port is discovered to be open.

$ nmap -p80 192.168.1.119

```
root@kali:~# nmap -p80 192.168.1.119
Starting Nmap 7.60 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2018-02-17 04:29 EST
Nmap scan report for 192.168.1.119
Host is up (0.00049s latency).
PORT   STATE SERVICE
80/tcp open  http
```

articles.title: Nmap Brute-Force Password Cracking
articles.content:
# Nmap Password Cracking using NSE Scripts

The Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE) is one of Nmap’s most powerful features. It enables users to write scripts to automate a wide variety of networking tasks. The 'brute' category of scripts uses brute force attacks to guess the authentication credentials of a remote server.

# Listing Brute-Force Scripts
To list all available NSE scripts for brute force attacks, you can use the locate command:
$ locate *.nse | grep brute

# FTP Brute-Force
This script performs password guessing against FTP servers.
$ nmap -p21 --script ftp-brute --script-args userdb=users.txt,passdb=pass.txt <target_ip>

# SSH Brute-Force
This script performs password guessing against SSH servers.
$ nmap -p22 --script ssh-brute --script-args userdb=users.txt,passdb=pass.txt <target_ip>

# Telnet Brute-Force
This script performs password guessing against Telnet servers.
$ nmap -p23 --script telnet-brute --script-args userdb=users.txt,passdb=pass.txt <target_ip>

# SMB Brute-Force
This script attempts to guess SMB username/password combinations.
$ nmap -p445 --script smb-brute --script-args userdb=users.txt,passdb=pass.txt <target_ip>

articles.title: How to Detect NMAP Scan Using Snort
articles.content:
# Detecting Nmap Scans with Snort

Snort is an open-source Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) capable of real-time traffic analysis and packet logging. It can be configured to detect various types of network reconnaissance, including Nmap scans.

# Basic Scan Detection
A simple TCP connect scan (-sT) from Nmap attempts a full three-way handshake with target ports. Snort can detect this rapid succession of SYN packets to multiple ports from a single source. A basic rule might look for this pattern.

# Stealth Scan Detection (FIN, Xmas, Null)
Stealth scans are designed to be less noisy.
* FIN Scan (-sF): Sends a FIN packet. Closed ports respond with RST.
* Xmas Scan (-sX): Sends a packet with FIN, PSH, and URG flags set.
* Null Scan (-sN): Sends a packet with no flags set.

Snort rules can be written to specifically look for these unusual flag combinations, which are characteristic of these scan types.

# Example Snort Rule for FIN Scan
```
alert tcp any any -> $HOME_NET any (msg:"NMAP FIN Scan Detected"; flags:F; sid:1000001; rev:1;)
```
This rule triggers an alert for any TCP packet with only the FIN flag set that is destined for your home network.

# Conclusion
Configuring Snort with a well-maintained ruleset is an effective way to detect reconnaissance activities from tools like Nmap, providing an early warning of a potential targeted attack.
